posts.title: [Zangwill] Preface
posts.text: A textbook, as opposed to a treatise, should include everything a student must know, not everything the author does know. --Kenneth Johnson, quoted by Francis Low (1997) Electrodynamics is important and challengingIt’s impossible to deny the permanent and important place of electrodynamics in the physics curriculum, along with classical mechanics, quantum mechanics, and statistical mechanics. But there are some reasons that make students find this is the most challenging, High mathematical demands of vector calculus and partial differential equations. The non-algorithmic nature of electromagnetic problem-solving. There are “two-level” structure of the theory, (a) the first one is the linear equations relates the electric and magnetic fields to their sources and to each other, (b) the second on is the quadratic equations relating the force, energy, and stress in the fields which are determined only indirectly by the first-layer quantities. Goal of this bookThis book is for graduate-level readers to help them deepen their understanding without minimizing the role of the mathematics. There are three considerations, This book serves both a classroom text and a reference book. The author’s struglle to apply the epigraph at the top of the page. Because the contents of a book about electrodynamics are usually depending on the research background of the writers, this book purposely contains much more material and offers more topics for discussion. Not only the problem can be considered via many angles, but also the mathematics and qualitative and physical arguments are impressive. Structure of this bookBased on the author’s instruction experience, the order and contents are well organized. The text is purposely repetitive to emphasis the important point and help students do not read the book in order. The items every chapter includes are listed as follows, Worked examples to develop problem-solving skills. Boxed excursions. Source, references, and additional reading. Homework problems. What “modern” meansThe “modern” dosen’t mean that it’s associated with the use of modern mathematicalo methods. On the opposite, (a) on the one hand, there are some modern topics arise in the recent years are included in this book. (b) On the other hand, there is an overview of Dirac’s Hamiltonian approach to electrodynamics and an update on certain “perpetual” problems like the correctness of the Lorentz-Dirac equation of motion for classical point particles. Some choices The author use SI units throughout because of it has become the world wide standard and he also procides an algorithm to painlessly convert from SI to Gaussian and vice versa. The author use the imaginary number $i$ to impose the metric in special relativity because the author thinks it more pedagogical.

posts.title: [Haake 2010] Chapter  1 Introduction
posts.text: Differences between classical regular motion and chaos There are two kinds of motion in classical Hamiltonian mechanics, regular motion of integrable systems examples: harmonic oscillator, Kepler problem. Lyapunov exponent grows exponentially with time. chaotic motion of nonintegrable systems examples: periodically driven pendulum, autonomous conservative double pendulum. Lyapunov exponent grows as power of time and can be vanished. where Lyapunov exponent is defined as the growth rate of the distance between any two trajectories. Because neither subexponential nor exponential separation can prevail indefinitely, where limits are set by (1) Poincaré recurrences or (2) the accessible volume of phase space, which become effective only after regular or chaotic behavior is manifest. Characteristic of quantum chaos and regular motion When quantum effects are important, (1) notion of phase-space trajectory and (2) Lyapunov exponent lose meaning. In quantum systems whose energy spectrum is discrete, there is no exponential separation even for expectation dynamics is characterized by quasi-periodicity (recurrences), where quasi-period (typical recurrence time) is (1) inversely proportional to a typical level spacing, and (2) tend to infinity in the classical limit (ℏ→0\hbar\to0ℏ→0). So, the question about the distinction between regular motion and chaos in quantum mechanics is proposed, In the limit of ℏ→0\hbar\to0ℏ→0, one group should become regular and the other become chaos. Quantum mechanical distinction criteria based on the (1) energy spectrum, (2) eigenvectors, or (3) temporal evolution of suitable expectation values should exist. Experiments with classical waves, electromagnetic, and sound provide some insights, (1) fields can be real, complex, or vector, (2) wave equation can be linear or nonlinear, in all cases, trajectories arises in the limit of short wavelengths, and they are chaotic with positive Lyapunov exponents whenever the underlying wave problem is nonseparable. This figures shows the quantum irregular motion which has classical counterpart displays (1) quasi-periodicity of the mean temporal separation of recurrences, and (2) its overlap of wo wave functions remains time-independent, ∣⟨ϕ(t)∣ψ(t)⟩∣2=∣⟨ϕ(0)∣ψ(0)⟩∣2|\langle\phi(t)|\psi(t)\rangle|^2=|\langle\phi(0)|\psi(0)\rangle|^2∣⟨ϕ(t)∣ψ(t)⟩∣2=∣⟨ϕ(0)∣ψ(0)⟩∣2 due to the unitarity of quantum dynamics. For each curve, the two states involved originate from one and the same initial state but evolve with slightly different values of one control parameters. For the initial state residing in the classically chaotic region, however, the overlap falls exponentially, down to a level of order 1/j1/j1/j, and the regular counterpart remains close to unity at all times. It’s indicated that sensitivity of the overlap to changes of a control parameter may indeed serve as a quantum criterion of irregular motion, which is called fidelity decay. Levels repulsion For classically integrable system, there are two or more degrees of freedom, quantum levels tends to cluster and are not prohibited from crossing when a parameters in the Hamiltonian is varied, The typical distribution of the spacings of neighboring levels is exponential, P(S)=exp⁡(−S)P(S)=\exp(-S)P(S)=exp(−S). For classically nonintegrable systems, levels are correlated and crossings are strongly resisted. There are three universal degrees of level repulsion, linear, quadratic, and quartic, P(S)∼Sβ for S→0 with β=1,2,4.P(S)\sim S^\beta\;\text{for}\;S\to0\;\text{with}\;\beta=1,2,4.P(S)∼SβforS→0withβ=1,2,4. These universality classes are determined by symmetries. There are some experimental evidences for linear and quadratic repulsion. There are some difficulties for experimental observations.

posts.title: Be carefull with precision issue in Numpy
posts.text: The complex type in Numpy According to the official document of Numpy, numpy.complex128 is composed of 2 64-bit-precision floating-point numbers. So, the numpy.complex64 is composed of 2 32-bit-precision floating-point numbers, which might lead to a loss of precision when you assign a numpy.float64 to a numpy.ndarray whose dtype is numpy.complex64. An example At first, we generate two matrices whose type of elements are numpy.complex64 and numpy.float64, 12345678910>>> import numpy as np>>> A = np.zeros((3, 3), dtype = np.complex64)>>> A.dtypedtype('complex64')>>> B = np.random.randn(2, 2)>>> B.dtypedtype('float64')>>> Barray([[-1.39295264, -1.93480849], [-0.18605461, -0.2380665 ]]) now we try to assign the elements of B to A, 1234567>>> A[0:2, 0:2] = B>>> A.dtypedtype('complex64')>>> Aarray([[-1.3929527+0.j, -1.9348085+0.j, 0. +0.j], [-0.1860546+0.j, -0.2380665+0.j, 0. +0.j], [ 0. +0.j, 0. +0.j, 0. +0.j]], dtype=complex64) we can see that the dtype of A is still complex64, and now we calculate the singular values of A by scipy.linalg.svdvals, 123456>>> from scipy.linalg import svdvals>>> siv = svdvals(A)>>> siv.dtypedtype('float32')>>> sivarray([2.4031136 , 0.01180331, 0. ], dtype=float32) As a result, the dtype of singular values is numpy.float32. Solution We should always fix the number of complex as the two times of float. 12345678910111213141516171819202122232425>>> A = np.zeros((3,3), dtype= np.complex128)>>> B = np.random.randn(2, 2)>>> Aarray([[0.+0.j, 0.+0.j, 0.+0.j], [0.+0.j, 0.+0.j, 0.+0.j], [0.+0.j, 0.+0.j, 0.+0.j]])>>> A.dtypedtype('complex128')>>> Barray([[-0.0713599 , 1.52210386], [-0.74102553, -0.6968513 ]])>>> B.dtypedtype('float64')>>> A[0:2, 0:2] = B>>> Aarray([[-0.0713599 +0.j, 1.52210386+0.j, 0. +0.j], [-0.74102553+0.j, -0.6968513 +0.j, 0. +0.j], [ 0. +0.j, 0. +0.j, 0. +0.j]])>>> A.dtypedtype('complex128')>>> siv = svdvals(A)>>> siv.dtypedtype('float64')>>> sivarray([1.69531001, 0.6946488 , 0. ])
